body: @dbczumar I'm just taking a look, not sure if I can help with this yet. A user can currently create either an endpoint or a batch transform job on SageMaker. The `BaseDeploymentClient` only exposes a single function `create_deployment` to deploy a model. Should the user still be able to create a batch transform job after this migration?

Hi @tmnhat2001, thanks for weighing in! I think we can keep the batch transform capabilities in `mlflow.sagemaker` to start with and focus on migrating the real-time scoring endpoint deployment piece.

@dbczumar Thanks for the explanation! I would like to take on this task.

Do we want to deprecate the following functionalities from `mlflow.sagemaker`?
```
mlflow.sagemaker.deploy()
mlflow.sagemaker.push_image_to_ecr()
mlflow.sagemaker.delete()
```

Also, is it ok to split this work into multiple PR's and merge them into master one after another? A single PR might get really big.

@tmnhat2001 Yes, ideally we should deprecate the existing functionalities as long as they can be replicated in the deployment plugin structure - great question!

Feel free to split the work into multiple PRs, and thank you in advance for your contribution! We're very excited about this effort!

@dbczumar The deployment function `mlflow.sagemaker.deploy()` currently accepts 3 modes: CREATE, REPLACE and ADD. When the mode is REPLACE or ADD, if a SageMaker Endpoint does not exist, the function will create the endpoint instead of raising an error.

The plugin interface exposes 2 functions `create_deployment()` and `update_deployment()`. I'm thinking of splitting these deployment modes like this:
- `create_deployment()`: always use CREATE mode
- `update_deployment()`: only accept REPLACE and ADD mode, raise an error if CREATE mode is used

However, this will become inconsistent with the current behaviour of `mlflow.sagemaker.deploy()`. Do we want to keep the behaviour of `mlflow.sagemaker.deploy()` that creates a new endpoint when there is no existing endpoint and the mode is REPLACE OR ADD?

@dbczumar The current function to delete SageMaker deployments requires more arguments than the function in the plugin interface.
Current function: https://github.com/mlflow/mlflow/blob/add4ece2c3a1e685bebd0c05436ec108462a9657/mlflow/sagemaker/__init__.py#L407

Plugin interface: https://github.com/mlflow/mlflow/blob/add4ece2c3a1e685bebd0c05436ec108462a9657/mlflow/deployments/base.py#L134

I can think of these options to implement the delete function according to the plugin interface:
- Read an environment variable to get the AWS region. The downside is that we lose the ability to customize the other parameters, unless we want to read them from the environment variables as well.
- Change the plugin interface to accept a config dictionary. This breaks backward compatibility with the current plugins

What do you think about this?

The functions `list_deployments()` and `get_deployment()` of the plugin have similar issues. They only accept the deployment name as an argument, but the user needs to be able to specify the AWS region as well.

Hi @tmnhat2001, apologies for the delayed reply. Your proposal for splitting the existing `mlflow.sagemaker.deploy()` functionality into `create_deployment()` and `update_deployment()` sounds great!

Regarding the limited interface for `delete_deployment()`, `list_deployments()`, and `get_deployment()`:

1. For `delete_deployment()`, since this operation modifies deployment state, I think it's acceptable to introduce a `config` parameter as a keyword-argument. For backwards compatibility, we can check if `config` is specified and, if it isn't, avoid passing it to the underlying plugin implementation. We can also use `inspect.signature()` to check if the plugin implementation accepts this parameter.

2. For `list_deployments()` and `get_deployment()`, since these are read operations, it would be nice to avoid adding configuration arguments. Instead, can we consider how to embed region information into the deployment's `target_uri`? Ideally, the `target_uri` should specify the relevant AWS account and region containing the endpoint(s).

Thanks a bunch for your contributions! I'll take a look at https://github.com/mlflow/mlflow/pull/4971 shortly - I like how we're initially introducing the plugin as `@experimental` and leaving the preexisting solution intact - that's awesome!
@dbczumar No worries at all! That PR is quite long :sweat_smile:. Both of your suggestions look very interesting. I'll try them out, thanks!
